table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a square or rectangular tub used to hold food while fermenting.

table.name: mem
table.column: James Randi is a famous magician.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a true wizard or sorcerer. For a magician, see {mIn yuqwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has negative connotations, and is considered quite insulting when applied to a person.[1, p.167]

table.name: mem
table.column: In {voSpegh Sep:n}, this is used instead of {ghaw':n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The plural of this is formed with {-mey:n:suff}.[1]
Human antibodies come in five immunoglobulin classes, referred to as IgA, IgD, IgM, IgE, and IgG.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tlhIngan 'IH qaD DaQap.:sen@@tlhIngan:n, 'IH:v, qaD:n, Da-:v, Qap:v:1} "Win Klingon beauty contest."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The request was for a word for "be a hypocrite". The response was to use the existing word {'Il:v:nolink} (which is in {TKD:src}) with the {-Ha':v} suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column: While the general word for "boil" is {pub:v}, the verb used specifically to refer to the boiling of fat is {'Im:v:nolink}.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: A pyramid with a three-sided base is called a {qu'vu':n}. A pyramid with an n-sided base is an {n reD 'Impey':n:nolink} for n > 3. For example: {loS reD 'Impey':n@@loS:n:1,num, reD:n:2, 'Impey':n}, {vagh reD 'Impey':n@@vagh:n:1,num, reD:n:2, 'Impey':n}. A cone is a {gho 'Impey':n}.
"I. M. Pei" is the architect who designed the pyramid at the Louvre.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the whole sewer system: tunnels, conduits, valves, etc.

table.name: mem
table.column: Backwards of {yIt:v} "walk" and {mI':v} "dance", a reference to the song "Walk the Llama Llama" from The Emperor's New Groove.

table.name: mem
table.column: sound made by a {vIghro':n} or a {ghISnar:n}

table.name: mem
table.column: A particular percussion instrument may be struck with the palm ({toch:n}; the verb is {weq:v}), the fist ({ro':n}; the verb is {tlhaw':v}), or a stick ({mupwI'Hom:n} if it resembles a small hammer, {naQHom:n} if a plain stick; the verb is {moq:v}).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This anagram alludes to a line from a Christopher Nolan movie.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the bright part of a plant.
A reference to the novel "Flower Drum Song" by C. Y. Lee (see {'In:n}), or the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical of the same name.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz insisted that this was a proper Klingon word.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: To make an {'Ip:n} is to {'Ip:v} or {lay':v}; to keep it is to {pab:v} the {'Ip:n}.[2]
This was defined as "oath" in {TKD:src}. The definition "promise" was added based on its translation in the {paq'batlh:src}.
▶ {tugh 'Ipvetlh Dapab DaneH'a'?:sen:nolink} "How would you like to keep that promise, very soon?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3}, {Sutay:n}, {veStay:n}, {Santay:n}, {'Iptay:n:nolink}.
This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

table.name: mem
table.column: be too much, be too many

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is not exactly the same as {QuchHa':v}, since the latter implies a change from being happy to not being happy.[2]
See {rav:n:1} for an idiom related to sadness.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {mejpu' SuvwI' 'e' vI'Ir:sen@@mej:v, -pu':v, SuvwI':n, 'e':n, vI-:v, 'Ir:v:1} "I guess the warrior has left"

table.name: mem
table.column: This means "creamy" in the sense of toothpaste. It describes smooth, thick liquids or liquid-like things.
It was clarified during the Q & A session that this could be used for both non-food and food.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used not just for children, but also adults.[3]

▶ {Da'Irghlu'chugh, potlhqu' Huch Daghaqbogh, 'ej yInmey lutoDlu'meH Qu' 'ut wItur 'e' QaH noblIj.:sen:nolink} "If you were bullied, money that you contribute is very important, and your gift will help us carry out an essential mission so that lives are saved."
[1] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src}), [2] {qep'a' 24 (2017):src}, [3] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a movement of air.

table.name: mem
table.column: The child of an {'IrneH:n:nolink} is a {lor:n:1}.
This is a reference to Uncle "Henry" from The Wizard of Oz.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is {DIS:n:2} plus {jar:n} with the first and last letters replaced.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to music only, and not to people getting along.
In the musical "The Music Man", Prof. Harold Hill turns four members of the River City school board into an impromptu barbershop quartet by getting each of them in turn to sing the word "ice-cream".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is something inherited from a predecessor, or what is left by a historical figure.
Tasha Yar's sister, Ishara Yar, was the central character in {TNG - Legacy:src}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word fits into a sentence in the place which would be occupied by the answer.[1] It works like a pronoun in questions with "to be" in the English translations.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a largish fruit with thorny projections on a reasonably hard shell or skin. The inside is more bitter than sweet (unlike an Earth pineapple, which may be referred to as a {tera' 'IventoH:n@@tera':n, 'IventoH:n}).[1]
Lake Ivanhoe in Orlando was once the centre of the US pineapple industry.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {HoS; 'Iw rur:sen@@HoS:v, 'Iw:n, rur:v}.

This sounds like what a human would say upon seeing blood.
It was confirmed during the Q & A session at {qep'a'2 27 (2020):src} that this is not grammatically considered a body part. Rather, it is a substance and does not take a plural suffix..

table.name: mem
table.column: I travel the river of blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: May you travel the river of blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is best served at {porgh Hat:n}.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: Sufficient blood wine does not exist.
This was the winning secrecy proverb entry, submitted by Lawrence Schoen ({'angghal:n:name,nolink}), in the proverbs competition at {qep'a' 21 (2014):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used in the preparation of {qagh:n}.[1, p.87]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a statue by the sculptor {mIStaq:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Listen to the voice of your blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: Watch a lesson on this toast: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/_mHUA5QKSG0}

When this toast first appeared in {CK:src}, it was thought that its grammar was incorrect. However, this toast was repeated in {PK:src}, where it was noted that toasts follow special grammar. This grammar was finally explained in {KGT:src} (see under {-jaj:v}).[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: My blood is thicker than yours.
This idiomatic phrase carries the meaning, "I am much stronger than you."

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was originally made up by Mark Shoulson to illustrate why people shouldn't make up words, since no one else would understand them. When MO heard about it, he turned it into a real word as a joke.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: a bug that sort of resembles a beetle
The name of the star Betelgeuse (popularly pronounced "beetle juice") was incorrectly thought to mean "the armpit of Orion".

table.name: mem
table.column: This isn't an exact translation, but {'I'SeghIm:n:nolink} is the closest Klingon equivalent to the English word "curmudgeon".[1]
This is a reference to "Isegrim" (or "Ysengrimus"), a wolf who is the chief character in a series of fables.
